SUN PACIFIC TULARE EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The refrigeration system at Sun PacificA?s Tulare facility provides process cooling for the facilityA?s two precooler rooms, three cold storage rooms, the hydrocooler, ten controlled atmosphere rooms, and associated hallways and dock areas.  Since the cold storage refrigeration system handles more than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, the Tulare facility has developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) program for the refrigeration system.  

Sun Pacific also operates a chlorination system to generate chlorinated process water for the packing plant.  The chlorination system utilizes one ton containers for the chlorine source.  Since the chlorination process handles more than the 2,500 pound threshold quantity, Sun Pacific has also developed a PSM program for the chlorination process.    

The chlorination system incorporates many inherently safe design features.  These features include fail safe (vacuum open and spring close) flow valves in the vacuum feed regulator and ejectors that fail in the closed position.  As such, the equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

As part of the PSM programs, Sun Pacific completed process hazard analyses, developed written operating procedures, trained employees on the refrigeration system, and developed a mechanical integrity program for the ammonia refrigeration equipment.  In addition to plant personnel monitoring the operation of the refrigeration system on a daily basis, Sun Pacific has implemented a preventative maintenance program to ensure that the refrigeration equipment is maintained in good operating condition.  Properly maintained equipment reduces the risk of an accidental release.

Additionally, Sun Pacific emphasizes safe and environmentally sound operating practices and procedures through their employee training programs.  In addition to job specific an

d process specific training, operators and maintenance personnel receive training in fire prevention, fire control, accident prevention, safety, and first aid.  

While it is Sun PacificA?s objective to be a responsible citizen of the community in all of its business activities, the limited staff at the Tulare facility precludes emergency response operations.  As such, an emergency action plan has been prepared for the Tulare facility and a chain of command to respond to emergencies has been established.

Sun Pacific has developed a detailed Compliance Audit Checklist which is used to evaluate compliance with the Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP regulations.  At least every three years, Sun Pacific audits these programs and any findings of noncompliance are documented and responded to and the deficiencies are corrected.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

 Sun Pacific owns and operates the Tulare facility located at 13129 Road 248 (approximately 3.6 miles east of Highway 99).  The closest population center to the packing house/cold storage facility is Tulare, which is approximately 3 miles southwest of the facility. 

The ammonia based refrigeration system consists of a suction accumulator with a liquid transfer system, six compressors, two evaporative condensers, a high pressure receiver, a hydrocooler, two precool rooms, three cold storage rooms, ten controlled atmosphere rooms, and fifteen direct expansion evaporators for cooling the hallways and dock areas.       

During normal operation, the anhydrous ammonia is distributed throughout the refrigeration system.  However, during major maintenance activities, the entire refrigeration system can be A?pumped downA? to evacuate the ammonia from the system and store it in the high pressure receiver.  The maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the high pressure receiver is 26,519 pounds. 

For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, the RMP regulations define the to

xic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).

Sun PacificA?s chlorination system is operated in a batch process that generates chlorinated water which is stored in a holding tank prior to being metered into process water at the packing plant.  In the chlorination process, fresh water is pumped through an ejector that creates a vacuum which draws chlorine gas from a vacuum feed regulator installed on a one ton container. A rotameter is installed in the vacuum tubing upstream of the ejector to regulate the flow of chlorine gas into the ejector where the chlorine gas mixes with the water.  This arrangement chlorinates the process water only when the fresh water pump is on and there is water flow through the ejector.  The maximum quantity in a one ton container is 2,000 pounds of chlorine.  

For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, the RMP regulations define the toxic endpoint for chlorine is defined as 0.0087 mg/l (3 ppm).  This concentration of chlorine has been established by the American Industrial Hygiene Association as the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release prevention program, has been developed by Sun Pacific to address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program, includes the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

A?    Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process has been compiled.

A?    Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) have been completed and will be updated and revalidated at least every five years.

A?    Written operating procedures will be reviewed at least annually.

A?    Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the facility are implemented as ne

eded.

A?    If employees are involved in operating the ammonia system, they will receive initial training and refresher training at least every three years.

A?    Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and implemented.

A?    A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed and implemented to address all proposed changes to the ammonia system.

A?    Pre-startup safety reviews will be performed when a modification is made to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.

A?    Audits will be conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance with the RMP regulations.

A?    Incident investigation procedures have been established.

A?    A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation has been developed and implemented.

A?    Hot work permits will be issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the ammonia system, as needed.

A?    A Contractor Safety Policy has been developed and implemented.

To ensure that the general accidental release prevention program and the chemical-specific prevention steps are implemented, Sun Pacific has assigned overall responsibility for the RMP elements to the Maintenance Manager.  The Maintenance Manager has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements.

Five-Year Accident History

The Sun Pacific Tulare facility has not had any accidental releases from the ammonia-based refrigeration system or the chlorination system that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program

Sun Pacific has established an emergency action plan and a chain of command to respond to emergencies and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.  However, an emergency response program doe

s not need to be developed for the facility since Sun Pacific employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia or chlorine, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan, and appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.  

Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Sun Pacific relies on the expertise of qualified ammonia refrigeration contractors to regularly evaluate the need for any changes to the refrigeration equipment and to improve safety.  Currently, Sun Pacific does not have any changes planned to improve safety associated with the ammonia refrigeration system or the chlorination system.
